I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 

1. 
to Georgia for the Regional Power Transmission Enhancement Project.1 
 
2. 
Georgia  is  endeavoring  to  develop  a  regional  power  market  comprising  Armenia, 
Azerbaijan, and Turkey, with Georgia serving as a transmission hub and as a seasonal exporter 
of  environmentally  clean  hydropower.  To  achieve  this,  in  addition  to  the  development  of 
hydropower  and  cross-border  transmission  facilities,  investments  are  required  to  upgrade 
system operation reliability and efficiency, and enhance transmission capacity. The project will 
include  three  main  components:  (i)  substation  rehabilitation  and  improvement,  (ii)  construction 
of a new Khorga 220/110-kilovolt (kV) substation, and (iii) consulting services.2 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

1. 

Sector Overview 

3. 
Georgia has made significant progress in energy sector reforms over the past  10 years 
to  address  chronic  power  shortages  and  the  poor  financial  condition  of  electricity  companies. 
During the 1990s, the sector experienced major technical and commercial challenges following 
the breakup of the former Soviet Union and a general collapse in payments within the sector. In 
1996,  the  existing  utility  was  unbundled  into  separate  generation,  transmission,  and  dispatch 
companies.  The  distribution  was  split  between  municipal  and  regional  companies.  Further 
reforms followed with the consolidation of regional distribution companies and the introduction of 
management contractors to manage the unified distribution company. The privatization of power 
generation  and  distribution  has  improved  management  of  operations.  Most  of  the  generation 
assets  have  been  privatized  with  the  exception  of  the  Enguri  hydropower  plant  (HPP),  the 
largest  HPP  with  an  installed  capacity  of  1,300  megawatts  (MW).  It  supplies  about  half  of  the 
country’s electricity needs. Distribution is fully privatized to foreign strategic investors. 
 
Georgian  State  Electrosystem  (GSE)  is  a  100%  state-owned  joint  stock  company 
4. 
providing  transmission  and  exclusive  dispatch  services  to  about  50  eligible  companies  in 
Georgia.  GSE  owns  most  of  the  transmission  grid  including  the  220  kV  and  110 kV  lines  and 
part of the 35 kV networks used for transmission services. GSE is also responsible for operation 
of the transmission system and owns the national dispatch center.  
 
5. 
The  reliability  of  electricity  services  has  improved  significantly  due  to  investments  in 
energy  infrastructure  and  maintenance.  Financial  viability  has  strengthened  with  tariff  reforms, 
improved  revenue  collection,  and  reduced  quasi-fiscal  deficits  in  the  sector.  Retail  tariffs  for 
residential  customers  are  set  close  to  full  cost  recovery  but  cross-subsidization  persists. 3 

                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).  2010.  Technical  Assistance  to  Georgia  for  Preparing  the  Regional  Power 

Transmission Enhancement Project. Manila. 

3  The Georgian National Energy and Water Regulatory Commission, the independent regulator, sets tariffs following 
methodology  and  procedures  set  out  in  its  Resolution  No.  3,  issued  on  1  July  1998.  The  current  tariffs  for 
residential  customers  are  GEL0.135–GEL0.177  per  kilowatt-hour  (kWh),  equivalent  to  $0.075–$0.099  per  kWh; 
these are reasonable by international and regional standards. 

 2 

 

The  country  possesses 

Collection  rates  increased  to  95%  in  2011.  Since  2006,  network  losses  have  been  reduced 
substantially, but remain high by international standards.4 
 
6. 
tremendous  untapped  hydropower  resources.  Currently, 
hydropower generation accounts for over 85% of annual energy output. Its hydropower potential 
is estimated at up to 80 terawatt-hours (TWh) per year, of which up to 60 TWh are economically 
feasible. The current system comprises about 60 HPPs with maximum output capability of 8.0–
9.5 TWh per year, i.e. 15% of the economically feasible potential. 
 
7. 
Since  2007,  generation  production  has  surpassed  the  annual  demand,  due  to  the 
rehabilitation  of  existing  HPPs,  improvement  in  the  efficiency  of  energy  use,  and  reduction  of 
losses.  Currently, Georgia has power trade with Armenia, Azerbaijan, Turkey, and the Russian 
Federation.  In  2011,  Georgia  exported  0.93  TWh  of  electricity,  accounting  for  10%  of  the 
country’s total electricity generation.5 
 
8. 
In 2008, the Government of Georgia launched a large hydropower investment promotion 
campaign and has since awarded a number of concession agreements for HPP construction. By 
2016–2017,  1,400  MW  of  new  HPPs  are  estimated  to  be  added  to  the  existing  2,510  MW  of 
HPPs, providing an additional 3.8 TWh of capacity available for export at an economic value to 
Georgia  of  $300  million  per  year.6 Of  Georgia’s  potential  export  markets,  Turkey  is  the  most 
attractive  given  its  summer  peak  in  demand,  projected  capacity  shortfalls,  and  high  market 
prices.7 Transit  trade  from  Armenia  and  Azerbaijan  to  Turkey  is  also  possible.  Power  transit 
through Turkey would mean that the rich energy resources in the Caucasus could eventually be 
exported  to  the  European  market.  Georgia  could  therefore  act  as  a  regional  hub  for  energy 
dispatch and transit through the Caucasus area. 
 

2. 

Key Problems and Constraints 

To develop the hydropower potential and expand power export, and especially to attract 
9.  
private  sector  capital  for  these  investments,  two  critical  technical  issues  need  to  be  resolved:  
(i)  ensure  the  stability,  reliability,  and  efficiency  of  Georgia’s  power  transmission  system;  and  
(ii) enlarge the transmission capacity and provide market access to the most promising export 
markets for surplus power. 
 
10.  
The  government  has  entered  into  agreements  with  neighboring  countries  to  enhance 
and  develop  transmission  infrastructure  and  interconnection  facilities  to  expand  power  trade. 
for 
New  cross-border 
commissioning  in  2013–2015. 8  At  present,  domestic  transmission  network  capacity  is 
inadequate and the operating system remains unstable and unreliable, increasing the potential 
                                                
4  The total transmission losses were reduced from 2.7% in  2006 to 1.9% in 2011. The total distribution losses in 2011 of 

lines  with  adjacent  countries  are  scheduled 

interconnection 

various distribution companies were 16.0%–27.0%. 

5  In 2011, Georgia’s export market shares are the Russian Federation, 63%; Turkey, 23%; Armenia, 13%; and Azerbaijan, 
1%.  Power  exports  were  during  the  summer  when  Georgia  had  excess  hydro  outputs  and  imports  were  during  winter. 
Total electricity imports in 2011 were 0.47 TWh, with 95% from the Russian Federation and 5% from Azerbaijan. 

6  Sector Assessment (Summary): Energy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
7  Wholesale  electricity  prices  in  Turkey  have  been  steadily  increasing  and  are  now  among  the  highest  among  energy 
community members. In 2011, the average wholesale electricity price in Turkey was €0.08 per kWh ($0.0102 per kWh). 
8  The Black Sea Transmission Network Project, a 500/400 kV interconnection line between Georgia and Turkey,  which will 
add 1,050 MW of additional interconnector capacity with Turkey, is ongoing and scheduled to be completed in 2013–2017 
in three phases. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the European Investment Bank, and German 
development cooperation through KfW are financing the project. The new 500 kV interconnection line between Georgia 
and  Azerbaijan  was  completed  in  2011.  A  new  400  kV  interconnection  line  between  Georgia  and  Armenia  is 
planned. 

 

 risk  of  frequent  system  blackouts.9 This  constrains  existing  and  future  power  swaps  or  export 
potential.  Since  2008,  considerable  investments  were  spent  to  rehabilitate  existing  substation 
facilities, mainly in primary equipment. However, the protection systems and substation control 
systems  supported  by  electromagnetic  analogue  technology  are  obsolete;  they  were  installed 
30–50  years  ago  and  have  serious  problems  meeting  operating  and  technical  requirements. 
Any fault on the existing transmission lines will result in a large power deficit in populated areas 
and  have  considerable  social  and  economic  impacts. 10  To  reduce  such  impacts,  more 
investment  is  urgently  required  for  substation  rehabilitation  and  enhancement  of  transmission 
facilities. 
 
11. 
The Georgian power system has a significant generation-load regional imbalance: two-
thirds of the energy resources are located in the northwest, while two-thirds of domestic demand 
is  located  in the  east.  Additionally,  most  of the  potential  export market  is  located to the  south. 
The  major  potential  export  market,  i.e.  Turkey,  is  experiencing  rapid  growth  in  electricity 
demand.  Other  countries,  such  as  Armenia  and  Azerbaijan,  while  experiencing  modest  or  at 
times  zero  demand  growth  are  likely  to  avail  of  a  relatively  cheap  supply  of  hydropower  from 
Georgia to augment and offset thermal and thermal-nuclear power generation. Power delivery to 
these markets requires a reliable high-voltage transmission network. 
 
The  new  Khorga  substation, 11  together  with  other  ongoing  transmission  investment 
12. 
projects,  will  improve  the  reliability  of  the  grid  and  quality  of  the  power  supply.  The  new 
substation  will  increase  transmission  capacity  by  an  additional  400  megavolt-amperes  (MVA), 
strengthening  and  stabilizing  the  transmission  network  operation.  It  will  guarantee  stable 
transmission  of  energy  produced  at  Enguri  HPP  to  the  industrial  zone  of  Poti  and  to  Turkey 
through  Batumi  substation. In addition,  it  will  help  stabilize transmission power  flows  providing 
additional event redundancy and lowering the incidence of outages. As energy trading between 
Georgia and Turkey stabilizes, the risk of incurring power trade contract penalties decreases. 
 
To accelerate hydropower development, the government asked the Asian Development 
13. 
Bank  (ADB)  to  consider  financing  a  run-of-the-river  HPP  with  40–50  MW  capacity.  The 
generated power will be required to meet the increased demand of domestic water utilities due 
to  rehabilitation  and  expansion  of  the  water  supply  system.12 Part  of  the  generation  may  be 
exported to neighboring countries.  
 

3. 

Sector Policy and Priorities 

The  government  recognizes  that  the  development  priority  for  power  is  the  effective 
14. 
development  and  utilization  of  rich  hydropower  resources.13 The  energy  sector  policy  has  a 
strong  focus  on  (i)  efficient  utilization  of  power  resources;  (ii)  rehabilitation  of  existing 
generation,  transmission,  and  distribution  facilities;  (iii)  interconnection  with  neighboring 
countries  to  promote  energy  trade,  including  transit;  and  (iv)  attraction  of  investment  and 
privatization. 
 

                                                
9  GSE system blackouts totaled 8 and 2 times, respectively, in 2010 and 2011—high by international standards. 
10 In  2007,  undelivered  energy  due  to  system  faults  totaled  1.2  gigawatt-hours,  representing  a  loss  to  Georgia  of 

$706,000 per annum. 

11 The Khorga substation is located near Khorga village in Khobi district of Samegrelo region in west Georgia. 
12 ADB  is  providing  a  multitranche  financing  facility  for  $500  million  to  support  Georgia’s  urban  water  supply  and 

sanitation sector development plan over 8 years from 2011 to 2020. 

13 The  government’s  power  policy  is  set  out  in the  Main  Directions  of  State  Policy  in  the  Power  Sector  of  Georgia, 

approved by Parliament on 7 June 2006. 

3 

 

 4 

 

Due  to  its  geographic  location,  the  government  aims  to  establish  Georgia  to  act  as  a 
15. 
transit  country  for  import–export  and  transit  operations  of  energy  carriers  in  the  Caucasus 
region. This will move the Caucasus countries closer to establishing a regional power market to 
facilitate flexible and mutually profitable cross-border energy exchanges. It will eventually result 
in regional energy resources being used in an efficient and environment-friendly way. 
 

4. 

ADB Operations and Sector Strategy 

 
Under  Strategy  2020,  ADB  will  support  regional  cooperation  activities  to  foster 
16. 
accelerated  economic  growth. 14 ADB  will  help  its  member  countries  realize  growth  through 
integration  and  closer  links  with  their  neighbors.  The  project  is  in  line  with  ADB's  strategy  for 
Georgia,  which  focuses  on  upgrading  and  developing  energy  infrastructure  and  enhancing 
regional energy trade by developing the Caucasus regional energy market.15 
 
17. 
ADB has not had lending in Georgia’s energy sector in relation to sovereign operations; 
the  project  provides  a  unique  opportunity  for  ADB  to  enter  the  sector.  Presently,  government 
funding is not sufficient on the scale needed for expanding and rehabilitating the power system. 
ADB’s  involvement  will  contribute  to filling  the funding gap  and  enhance the  confidence of  the 
private sector in investing in power. In addition, the project will complement other ADB support 
for infrastructure, including the development of the transport and water supply sectors. 
 
18. 
ADB will work with the government and development partners to improve the structural, 
legal,  and  regulatory  framework  needed  to  attract  private  sector  funding  in  the  sector. 
Substantial  progress  in  sector  reforms  and  strong  improvements  in  the  efficiency  of  power 
the 
operations  have  been  achieved.  This  has  generated  strong  commitment  among 
development community to continue supporting the sector through project financing, institutional 
reforms, and capacity building.16 
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

19. 
The  project  is  an  integral  part  of  Georgia’s  power  development  plan  and  the  selected 
components are under GSE’s investment priorities. The project objective is to enhance regional 
power  trade  by  (i)  rehabilitating  and  improving  11  existing  substations,  and  (ii)  constructing  a 
new substation. 
 
The  project  impact  will  be  the  contribution  to  expanding  Georgia’s  power  trade  in  the 
20. 
Caucasus  region.  Net  power  exports  are  expected  to  increase  from  10%  of  domestic  power 
generation (2011) to 20% by 2019. The project outcome will be a reliable, stable, and efficient 
power operating system to meet increasing demand for power export and transit. 
 
C. 

Outputs 

The project outputs consist of the following components: 

(i) 

Substation 
improvement.  Rehabilitate  11  existing 
substations  by  installing  modern  digital  control  and  relay  protection  systems  to 

rehabilitation  and

Manila. 

2017) is being prepared. 

16 Development Coordination (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

21. 
 

 

 achieve  full  functions  of  the  existing  supervisory  control  and  data  acquisition 
system  and  energy  management  system 
for  efficient  power  dispatching 
operation. 
Khorga  substation.  Construct  a  new  220/110  kV  substation  with  220  kV  and 
110 kV line bays and associated equipment. 
Project  supervision  and  management.  Provide  assistance  to GSE  for  project 
supervision and management. 
Study  of  potential  hydropower  investment  projects.  Help  the  government 
feasibility  studies  and  due  diligence  assessments  of 
conduct  necessary 
safeguards on future potential hydropower investment projects. 

(ii) 

(iii) 

(iv) 

Investment and Financing Plans 

 
D. 
 
22. 
The  project  is  estimated  to  cost  $67  million.  The  investment  plan  is  summarized  in  
Table  1.  The  government  has  requested  a  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to  SDR 
30,981,000 from ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance the project. The loan will have 
a term of 32 years including a grace period of 8 years, with interest at 1.0% per annum during 
the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and such other terms and conditions set forth 
in the draft loan and project agreements. The government will be the borrower for the ADB loan 
and relend it to GSE (excluding $2 million for the hydropower project study) on similar terms and 
conditions as the ADB loan. GSE will assume the foreign exchange risk.

23. 
The  government  and  GSE  will  contribute  $19  million  to  cover  value-added  tax  and 
customs duties accrued on project expenditures, financing charges during implementation, and 
contingencies  required.  The  financing  plan  is  summarized  in  Table  2.  The  detailed  cost

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

GSE  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  project,  except  for  the  study  on  potential 
24. 
hydropower investment projects, where the Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources (MOENR) 
will be the executing agency. 
 
The procurement capacity assessment revealed that GSE and MOENR have adequate 
25. 
capacity but have limited experience with ADB procedures. Several transmission and substation 
rehabilitation  projects  funded  by  other  international  development  partners,  such  as  the  World 
Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the European Investment Bank, 
and German development cooperation through KfW are under implementation with satisfactory 
performance. Goods and works to be financed under the project will be procured in accordance 
with  ADB's  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).18 ADB  approved 
advance procurement  action for  procurement  and  consultants. The government  and  executing 
agencies  have  been  advised  that  approval  of  advance  procurement  does  not  commit  ADB  to 
finance the project. 
 
26. 
GSE will recruit a consulting firm to support the existing Project Management Unit with 
project  supervision  and  management.  In  addition,  MOENR  will  recruit  a  consulting  firm  to 
undertake the feasibility  study and safeguards due diligence on potential hydropower projects. 
All  consulting  services  will  be  procured  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
27. 
the PAM (footnote 17).

Source: Asian Development Bank 
 

A. 

Technical 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

28. 
The  current  Georgian  power  operating  system  remains  unstable  and  unreliable. 
Rehabilitation and improvement of substation facilities through the installation of modern digital 
control  and  protection  systems  will  significantly  improve  system  reliability  and  security.  The 
protection  system  is  to  isolate  any  short  circuits  that  may  occur  in  the  system  in  a  time 
compatible  with  the  security  of  the  power  system.  During  short  circuits,  the  condition  of  the 
transmission system is unstable. The system must be returned to a stable situation as soon as 
possible by  isolating  the  short  circuit. Ongoing  instablity  may  lead  to  a voltage collapse and a 
regional  or  system  blackout.  Rehabilitation  of  substation  facilities  not  only  helps  GSE  deliver 
power  reliably  and  safely  to  customers  but  also  reduces  transmission  losses  and  lowers 
operating  costs.  The  new  Khorga  substation  will  enhance  transmission  capacity  to  meet  the 
increasing demand in the western part of Georgia, while the additional capacity will contribute to 
power  transmission  in  the  main  grid.  A  reliable  and  stable  power  transmission  system  is  a 
precondition  for  efficient  regional  power  trade  as  well  as  investments  in  hydropower 
development. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 

internal  rate  of  return, 

A financial analysis of the project was carried out in accordance with ADB’s guidelines.19 
29. 
All  financial  costs  and  benefits  are  expressed  at  constant  2012  prices.  Cost  streams  used  to 
determine  the  financial 
investment,  operation  and 
maintenance, and taxes, reflect the costs of delivering the estimated benefits. 
 
30. 
The project’s financial internal rate of return is 3.8%, which compares favorably with the 
estimated weighted average cost of capital of 0.2%, indicating expected financial viability for the 
project.  Financial  viability  was  gauged  by comparing  the  incremental  costs  and benefits  of the 
with-project and without-project investment scenarios. The incremental benefits arise from GSE 

i.e.  capital 

                                                
19 ADB. 2005. Financial Management and Analysis of Projects. Manila. 

7 

 

 8 

 

revenues  in  Georgia  as  well  as  those  accruing  to  the  region,  i.e.  to  Turkey  from  additional 
revenues  generated  from  the  ability  to  export.  Regional  financial  benefits  such  as  additional 
revenues generated in neighboring countries are not included in the financial evaluation. 
 
31. 
opportunity cost of capital in the country; this fully justifies investment in the project. 
 
C. 

The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  13.4%  compares  favorably  with  the  12.0% 

Governance 

32.   ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and GSE. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the PAM (footnote 17). 
 
33. 
GSE  has  adequate  capacity  to  manage  funds  flow  under  the  project.  Until  2006,  GSE 
operated  at  a significant  loss,  and  was nearly  bankrupt  because  of  the failure  of customers to 
pay  their  bills.  To  avert  bankruptcy,  in  2008  GSE  entered  into  a  legally  binding  rehabilitation 
plan with its creditors, mainly the Ministry of Finance. The plan sets out plans for investment and 
operating  expenditure  and  a  schedule  of  debt  repayment  in  15  years.  Revenue  collection 
problems  have  been  resolved  since  2007;  GSE  has  collected  most  of  the  invoiced  amounts. 
GSE reported a profit of GEL19.4 million in 2011.   
 
34. 
GSE  has  experience  in  managing  externally  financed  projects,  and  maintains  its 
accounting  and  reporting  procedures  according  to  international  financial  reporting  standards. 
The government has committed to specific financial performance for GSE. Periodic tariff reviews 
will  be  required  to  overcome  the  risk  of  poor  financial  performance  to  achieve  long-term 
sustainability,  and  to  ensure  that  the  project  does  not  have  an  adverse  fiscal  impact  on  GSE 
and  the  government.  Financial  management  risks  are  assessed  low  after  proposed  risk 
mitigation measures. 
 
D. 

Poverty and Social 

35. 
By increasing the supply of efficient and reliable electricity to the system, the project will 
increase  the  reliability  of  the  power  supply  nationwide,  benefiting  the  poor  and  neglected 
regions.  Since  the  rural  poor  are  the  first  to  be  cut  off  from  supply  during  winter  power 
shortages,20 system loss reduction and stronger supply reliability will particularly benefit the poor 
and the socially excluded. Women, who are mainly responsible for household tasks in Georgian 
families, will especially benefit from reliable power supply to households. The project will provide 
equal  opportunities  for  female  staff  to  avail  of  training  opportunities  required  to  operate  the 
supervisory  control  and  data  acquisition  system.  The  project  will  also  benefit  hydropower 
development  and  enhance  regional  power  export,  which  will  stimulate  economic  growth  and 
increase employment opportunities. 
 
E. 

Safeguards 

Environmental  assessment.  Only  the  construction  of  Khorga  substation  will  involve 
36. 
physical activities that could potentially result in environmental impacts. The project is classified 
under environment category B. An initial environmental examination, including an environmental 
management plan in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), was prepared 

                                                
20 Currently,  no  power  supply  deficits  (around  5%  of  the  total  domestic  demand)  during  the  winter  have  to  be 

balanced from imports. 

 

 and adopted by the government.21 No significant natural habitats will be affected by the Khorga 
substation  development  due  to  its  location  within  an  area  where  the  natural  habitat  has  been 
highly  modified  by  recent  agricultural  activities  and  human  settlement.  Overall,  the  project  will 
generate  only  minor  environmental  impacts  that  can  be  reduced  to  acceptable  levels  through 
implementation  of  practical  mitigation  measures  normally  associated  with  internationally 
recognized good engineering practice. 
 
37. 
Involuntary  resettlement.  Of  all  the  project  components,  only  the  construction  of  the 
Khorga  substation  will  entail  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  impacts.  These  impacts  are 
minor. The area required for the substation belongs to the government and no land acquisition 
will  be  needed.  However,  three  encroacher  families,  with  no  legal  rights,  cultivate  the  area. 
These families  will  be  provided  with  compensation for the  crop  income  they  lose  in  2013,  and 
with allowances for severe impacts and for vulnerable people (the families lose more than 10% 
of  their  income  and  are  registered  as  poor  by  the  province’s  Social  Services  Office).  The 
resettlement plan, in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), was prepared 
and adopted by the government.22 
 
38. 
Indigenous peoples. No indigenous people live in the project area. The project will not 
trigger  indigenous  peoples  safeguards  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement 
(2009). The project classification is C. No indigenous peoples development plan is required. 
 
F. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

39. 
The  government  fully  supports  the  project.  MOENR  will  coordinate  the  work  of 
government  agencies  to  ensure  that  issues,  if  any,  are  resolved  promptly.  Technologies 
adopted  under  the  project  conform  to  international  standards  and  best  practices  that  are 
commercially  proven  and  widely  used  internationally.  GSE  has  significant  experience  in 
managing  projects  in  cooperation  with  international  financial  institutions.  However,  it  remains 
resource-constrained  and  its  ability  to  manage  multiple  large  projects  is  uncertain  without  the 
support  of  external  international  expertise.  Another  potential  risk  relates  to  GSE’s  financial 
position:  a  low  ratio  of  available  cash  from  operations  to  current  capital  expenditure 
commitments and future debt service obligations, implying continued reliance by GSE on debt to 
fund capital expenditures with little ability to contribute from its own cash reserves.  Risks have 
been  analyzed  and  deemed  acceptable  or  mitigated.  Major  risks  and  mitigating  measures  are 
summarized in Table 4 and described in the risk assessment and risk management plan.23 
 

Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 

Risks 

GSE has limited project management 
capacity and lacks experience with 
turnkey contract management. 

Unsustainable cash flow from GSE 
operations to cover capital expenditure, 
debt obligations, and operation and 
maintenance costs. 

 

Mitigating Measures 

International consultants will undertake project design, bidding 
preparation support, and evaluation. Project supervision consultants 
will be recruited to help GSE with project implementation and 
management. 
The present cost-plus-tariff methodology sufficiently addresses 
immediate term needs and existing conditions in Georgia. The tariff 
regime allows GSE to apply to the independent tariff regulator—the 
Georgian National Energy and Water Regulatory Commission—to 
review the tariff methodology periodically.

Risks 

Delay, failure to complete planned 
interconnection facilities. 

Unexpected increase in prices of 
commodities and raw materials.

government approvals. 
Delays in construction due to

Mitigating Measures 

Bulk interconnection transmission lines are under construction and 
adequate financing resources are secured. Supervision consultants

Adequate contingency amounts will be provided. GSE will supplement 
any shortfall. Procurement is at an advanced stage so price increase 
risks and delay risks are minimized. 

ADB recruited experienced consultants under the project preparation 
technical assistance to support GSE in procuring competitive and 
experienced turnkey contractors. Experienced supervision consultants 
will be on-site to assist and monitor the turnkey contractors. 

ADB = Asian Development Bank, GSE = Georgian State Electrosystem.

IV. 

ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 

The government  and GSE  have  agreed  with  ADB  on  certain  covenants for  the  project, 

40. 
The  government  and  GSE  have  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the  project  shall 
conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies,  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and loan documents. 
 
41. 
which are set forth in the loan and project agreements. 
 
42. 
No  withdrawal  will  be  made  until  after  a  subsidiary  loan  agreement,  in  form  and 
substance  satisfactory  to  ADB,  has  been  duly  authorized  or  ratified  by,  and  executed  and 
delivered on behalf of, the government and GSE. 
 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

43. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  in  various 
currencies  equivalent  to  SDR30,981,000  to  Georgia  for  the  Regional  Power  Transmission 
Enhancement Project, from ADB’s Special Funds resources, with an interest charge at the rate 
of  1.0%  per  annum  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5%  per  annum  thereafter;  for  a  term  of  
32  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  8  years;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  and  project  agreements 
presented to the Board. 
 

Haruhiko Kuroda 
President
